message: As an exercise, I've been running djangobench over the 1.2.X tree for awhile and tossing the results into speedcenter: http://django-speedcenter.improbable.org/

The big one is that there's no UI for separating multiple projects - I'd love to turn something like this into a more general service where e.g. django-cms or pinax, etc. could maintain an example project and track it over time
One obvious addition would be collecting memory usage or database stats for djangobench
Since Djangy is going to be shutting down, I'm thinking about where to move it and was also wondering what other valuable things people would like to track like this
but it also seems like there might be value in, say, tracking a realistic test project using something substantial like a CMS and measuring that performance over time as well.
@acdha we'd be happy to host the Django speed center app at DjangoZoom. http://djangozoom.com Sign up for the beta and we'll send you an invite.
Yeah, that'd be very cool but hard
cool to see the speedcenter code being reused
ep.io'd probably host it
and bringing it full-circle, I'd like to track all of this on pypy vs. cpython…
I need to play with djangobench more - the couple times I've tried to use it, I haven't been able to get much in the way of meaningful results out of it. Too much noise.
I'm actually working with tobami to get some improvements to speedcenter
I also want to dig into the speedcenter code a bit and make sure we have a nice API for getting data out
I might actually work on that on the way to PyCon as a nice warmup - the data model's there but the URL syntax isn't so it'd be an easy addition

It would be nice if we could somehow combine something like coverage.py's html output with a commit diff to show what lines actually changed and ran during the benchmark.  That might help expose unnecessary performance regressions. </featurecreep>
e.g. dygraphs is nice for plotting lots of time-series with min/max or stddev and it'd be nice if you could play with that simply by setting up an HTML page somewhere & referencing the data
Wow, that looks great.  I wish I'd known about codespeed before I wrote http://github.com/sebleier/djangobench-webui
The lines are all looking pretty flat there.
Probably a dedicated system not doing anything else is the first step.
@carljm One note: it's all 1.2.X because for awhile djangobench died on 1.3. I imagine 1.3 would show more effect
@natea Will do - thanks!
I still need to tweak the github backend a bit - and I've been meaning just to roll their embeded diff UI in
I also had to borrow a spare Linux box to make sure I have a low-noise test box
